Hey! You only have two sign-in methods. If you lose that and have only one left, you will be locked out of your account forever.

Instead, we use multiple sign-in methods:
Instead, we use multiple sign-in methods for security and account recovery purposes. 
Each time you log in with your cryptowallet, Google, Facebook, or Github, 
you’ll be asked for one of the sign-in methods below:
I’m done saving my backup phrase: I’m done saving my backup phrase

Previously, you required a password to a:
Previously, you required a password to access your Files account. 
We’re happy to announce that you don’t need a password to sign in anymore. 
All you have to do is set up multiple sign-in methods.
Save this browser for next time?: Save this browser for next time?
Setting these up means you’ll be able to:
Setting these up means you’ll be able to recover your account if you do get locked out somehow. 
Here’s what you can do now:
Setting up multiple sign-in methods make: Setting up multiple sign-in methods makes signing in on multiple devices and restoring your account a breeze, all done without us storing information about you. Think that’s cool? <0>Learn how we apply cryptography to ensure the privacy of your data.</0>

We seriously advise that you add a third: We seriously advise that you add a third method. If you lose one of the two sign-in methods, you’ll lose access to your account forever. Plus, signing in on multiple devices will be easier.

Welcome! Here at Files we don’t require: Welcome! Here at Files we don’t require emails and phone numbers to set up an account.
Without setting up at least three authen: Without setting up at least three authentication factors, you risk getting locked out of your account.<0/><1/>Remember, you need a minimum of two factors to sign in. If you only have one, you’ll lose access to your account forever.
You will need to sign a message in your: You will need to sign a message in your wallet to complete sign in.
Your recovery key can be used to restore: Your recovery key can be used to restore your account in place of your backup phrase.
